"d:Q176503")]  
  
The **femur** ([/ˈfiːmər/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English "Help:IPA/English"), pl.
_femurs_ or _femora_ [/ˈfɛmərə/](/wiki/Help:IPA/English
"Help:IPA/English"))[1][2] or thigh bone, is the most
[proximal](/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_location#Proximal_and_distal "Anatomical
terms of location") (closest to the hip joint) [bone](/wiki/Bone "Bone") of
the [leg](/wiki/Leg "Leg") in [tetrapod](/wiki/Tetrapod "Tetrapod")
[vertebrates](/wiki/Vertebrate "Vertebrate") capable of
[walking](/wiki/Walking "Walking") or [jumping](/wiki/Jumping "Jumping"), such
as most land [mammals](/wiki/Mammal "Mammal"), [birds](/wiki/Bird "Bird"),
many [reptiles](/wiki/Reptile "Reptile") including [lizards](/wiki/Lizard
"Lizard"), and [amphibians](/wiki/Amphibian "Amphibian") such as
[frogs](/wiki/Frog "Frog"). In vertebrates with four legs such as
[dogs](/wiki/Dog "Dog") and [horses](/wiki/Horse "Horse"), the femur is found
only in the [hindlimbs](/wiki/Hindlimb "Hindlimb"). The [head of the
femur](/wiki/Femur_head "Femur head") articulates with the
[acetabulum](/wiki/Acetabulum "Acetabulum") in the [pelvic
bone](/wiki/Pelvic_bone "Pelvic bone") forming the [hip joint](/wiki/Hip_joint
"Hip joint"), while the [distal part of the
femur](/wiki/Lower_extremity_of_femur "Lower extremity of femur") articulates
with the [tibia](/wiki/Tibia "Tibia") and [kneecap](/wiki/Kneecap "Kneecap")
forming the [knee joint](/wiki/Knee_joint "Knee joint"). By most measures the
femur is the strongest bone in the body. The femur is also the longest bone in
the human body.

## Structure[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=1 "Edit
section: Structure")]

The femur is the only bone in the upper [leg](/wiki/Leg "Leg"). The two femurs
converge [medially](/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_location "Anatomical terms of
location") toward the [knees](/wiki/Knee "Knee"), where they articulate with
the [proximal](/wiki/Anatomical_terms_of_location "Anatomical terms of
location") ends of the [tibiae](/wiki/Tibia "Tibia"). The angle of convergence
of the femora is a major factor in determining the [femoral-tibial
angle](/wiki/Femoral-tibial_angle "Femoral-tibial angle"). Human females have
wider [pelvic bones](/wiki/Pelvic_bone "Pelvic bone"), causing their femora to
converge more than in males. In the condition [_genu valgum_ (knock
knee)](/wiki/Genu_valgum "Genu valgum") the femurs converge so much that the
knees touch one another. The opposite extreme is [_genu varum_ (bow-
leggedness)](/wiki/Genu_varum "Genu varum"). In the general population of
people without either _genu valgum_ or _genu varum_ , the femoral-tibial angle
is about 175 degrees.[3]

The femur is the longest and, by most measures, the strongest bone in the
human body. Its length on average is 26.74% of a person's height,[4] a ratio
found in both men and women and most [ethnic groups](/wiki/Ethnic_group
"Ethnic group") with only restricted variation, and is useful in
[anthropology](/wiki/Anthropology "Anthropology") because it offers a basis
for a reasonable estimate of a subject's height from an incomplete
[skeleton](/wiki/Human_skeleton "Human skeleton").

The femur is categorised as a [long bone](/wiki/Long_bone "Long bone") and
comprises a [diaphysis](/wiki/Diaphysis "Diaphysis") (shaft or
[body](/wiki/Body_of_femur "Body of femur")) and two
[epiphyses](/wiki/Epiphysis "Epiphysis") (extremities) that articulate with
adjacent bones in the hip and knee.[3]

### Upper part[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=2 "Edit
section: Upper part")]

Main article: [Upper extremity of femur](/wiki/Upper_extremity_of_femur "Upper
extremity of femur")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/97/Gray243.png/275px-
Gray243.png)](/wiki/File:Gray243.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray243.png "Enlarge")

The [upper extremity](/wiki/Upper_extremity_of_femur "Upper extremity of
femur") of right femur viewed from behind and above, showing
[head](/wiki/Femur_head "Femur head"), [neck](/wiki/Neck_of_femur "Neck of
femur"), and the [greater](/wiki/Greater_trochanter "Greater trochanter") and
[lesser trochanter](/wiki/Lesser_trochanter "Lesser trochanter")

The [upper](/wiki/Upper_extremity_of_femur "Upper extremity of femur") or
proximal extremity (close to the [torso](/wiki/Torso "Torso")) contains the
[head](/wiki/Femur_head "Femur head"), [neck](/wiki/Neck_of_femur "Neck of
femur"), the two [trochanters](/wiki/Human_trochanter "Human trochanter") and
adjacent structures.[3]

The [head of the femur](/wiki/Femur_head "Femur head"), which
[articulates](/wiki/Joint_\(anatomy\) "Joint \(anatomy\)") with the
[acetabulum](/wiki/Acetabulum "Acetabulum") of the [pelvic
bone](/wiki/Pelvic_bone "Pelvic bone"), comprises two-thirds of a
[sphere](/wiki/Sphere "Sphere"). It has a small groove, or
[fovea](/wiki/Fovea_of_head_of_femur "Fovea of head of femur"), connected
through the [round ligament](/wiki/Ligament_of_head_of_femur "Ligament of head
of femur") to the sides of the [acetabular notch](/wiki/Acetabular_notch
"Acetabular notch"). The head of the femur is connected to the
[shaft](/wiki/Shaft_of_femur "Shaft of femur") through the
[neck](/wiki/Neck_of_femur "Neck of femur") or _collum_. The neck is 4–5 cm.
long and the diameter is smallest front to back and compressed at its middle.
The collum forms an angle with the shaft in about 130 degrees. This angle is
highly variant. In the [infant](/wiki/Infant "Infant") it is about 150 degrees
and in [old age](/wiki/Old_age "Old age") reduced to 120 degrees on average.
An abnormal increase in the angle is known as [coxa valga](/wiki/Coxa_valga
"Coxa valga") and an abnormal reduction is called [coxa vara](/wiki/Coxa_vara
"Coxa vara"). Both the head and neck of the femur is vastly embedded in the
[hip musculature](/wiki/Muscles_of_the_hip "Muscles of the hip") and can not
be directly [palpated](/wiki/Palpation "Palpation"). In skinny people with the
thigh laterally rotated, the head of the femur can be felt deep as a
resistance [profound](/wiki/Profound "Profound") (deep) for the [femoral
artery](/wiki/Femoral_artery "Femoral artery").[3]

The transition area between the head and neck is quite rough due to attachment
of muscles and the [hip joint capsule](/wiki/Capsule_of_hip_joint "Capsule of
hip joint"). Here the two [trochanters](/wiki/Human_trochanter "Human
trochanter"), [greater](/wiki/Greater_trochanter "Greater trochanter") and
[lesser trochanter](/wiki/Lesser_trochanter "Lesser trochanter"), are found.
The greater trochanter is almost box-shaped and is the most
[lateral](/wiki/Lateral_\(anatomy\) "Lateral \(anatomy\)") prominent of the
femur. The highest point of the greater trochanter is located higher than the
collum and reaches the midpoint of the [hip joint](/wiki/Hip_joint "Hip
joint"). The greater trochanter can easily be felt. The [trochanteric
fossa](/wiki/Trochanteric_fossa "Trochanteric fossa") is a deep depression
bounded posteriorly by the intertrochanteric crest on medial surface of the
greater trochanter. The lesser trochanter is a cone-shaped extension of the
lowest part of the femur neck. The two trochanters are joined by the
[intertrochanteric crest](/wiki/Intertrochanteric_crest "Intertrochanteric
crest") on the back side and by the [intertrochanteric
line](/wiki/Intertrochanteric_line "Intertrochanteric line") on the front.[3]

A slight ridge is sometimes seen commencing about the middle of the
intertrochanteric crest, and reaching vertically downward for about 5 cm.
along the back part of the body: it is called the [linea
quadrata](/wiki/Linea_quadrata "Linea quadrata") (or quadrate line).

About the junction of the upper one-third and lower two-thirds on the
intertrochanteric crest is the [quadrate tubercle](/wiki/Quadrate_tubercle
"Quadrate tubercle") located. The size of the tubercle varies and it is not
always located on the intertrochanteric crest and that also adjacent areas can
be part of the quadrate tubercel, such as the posterior surface of the greater
trochanter or the neck of the femur. In a small anatomical study it was shown
that the [epiphysial line](/wiki/Epiphyseal_plate "Epiphyseal plate") passes
directly through the quadrate tubercle.[5]

### Body[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=3 "Edit section:
Body")]

Main article: [Body of femur](/wiki/Body_of_femur "Body of femur")

The [body of the femur (or shaft)](/wiki/Body_of_femur "Body of femur") is
long, slender and almost cylindrical in form. It is a little broader above
than in the center, broadest and somewhat flattened from before backward
below. It is slightly arched, so as to be convex in front, and concave behind,
where it is strengthened by a prominent longitudinal ridge, the [linea
aspera](/wiki/Linea_aspera "Linea aspera") which diverges proximal and distal
as the medial and lateral ridge. Proximal the lateral ridge of the linea
aspera becomes the [gluteal tuberosity](/wiki/Gluteal_tuberosity "Gluteal
tuberosity") while the medial ridge continues as the [pectineal
line](/wiki/Pectineal_line_\(femur\) "Pectineal line \(femur\)"). Besides the
linea aspera the shaft has two other bordes; a [lateral and medial
border](/wiki/Body_of_femur#Lateral_border_and_medial_border "Body of femur").
These three bordes separates the shaft into three surfaces: One
[anterior](/wiki/Body_of_femur#Anterior_surface "Body of femur"), one medial
and one lateral. Due to the vast [musculature of the
thigh](/wiki/Thigh#Muscles_and_fascia "Thigh") the shaft can not be
[palpated](/wiki/Palpation "Palpation").[3]

The [third trochanter](/wiki/Third_trochanter "Third trochanter") is a bony
projection occasionally present on the proximal femur near the superior border
of the gluteal tuberosity. When present, it is oblong, rounded, or conical in
shape and sometimes continuous with the gluteal ridge.[6] A structure of minor
importance in humans, the incidence of the third trochanter varies from 17–72%
between ethnic groups and it is frequently reported as more common in females
than in males.[7]

### Lower part[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=4 "Edit
section: Lower part")]

Main article: [Lower extremity of femur](/wiki/Lower_extremity_of_femur "Lower
extremity of femur")

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/53/Gray246.png/220px-
Gray246.png)](/wiki/File:Gray246.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray246.png "Enlarge")

Lower extremity of right femur viewed from below.

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/19/Gray348.png/220px-
Gray348.png)](/wiki/File:Gray348.png)

[](/wiki/File:Gray348.png "Enlarge")

Left [knee joint](/wiki/Knee_joint "Knee joint") from behind, showing interior
ligaments.

The [lower extremity of the femur](/wiki/Lower_extremity_of_femur "Lower
extremity of femur") (or distal extremity) is larger than the [upper
extremity](/wiki/Upper_extremity_of_femur "Upper extremity of femur"). It is
somewhat cuboid in form, but its transverse diameter is greater than its
antero-posterior (front to back). It consists of two oblong eminences known as
the [condyles](/wiki/Condyle_\(anatomy\) "Condyle \(anatomy\)").[3]

Anteriorly, the condyles are slightly prominent and are separated by a smooth
shallow articular depression called the patellar surface. Posteriorly, they
project considerably and a deep notch, the [Intercondylar fossa of
femur](/wiki/Intercondylar_fossa_of_femur "Intercondylar fossa of femur"), is
present between them. The [lateral condyle](/wiki/Lateral_condyle_of_femur
"Lateral condyle of femur") is the more prominent and is the broader both in
its antero-posterior and transverse diameters. The [medial
condyle](/wiki/Medial_condyle_of_tibia "Medial condyle of tibia") is the
longer and, when the femur is held with its body perpendicular, projects to a
lower level. When, however, the femur is in its natural oblique position the
lower surfaces of the two condyles lie practically in the same horizontal
plane. The condyles are not quite parallel with one another; the long axis of
the lateral is almost directly antero-posterior, but that of the medial runs
backward and medialward. Their opposed surfaces are small, rough, and concave,
and form the walls of the [intercondyloid
fossa](/wiki/Anterior_intercondyloid_fossa "Anterior intercondyloid fossa").
This fossa is limited above by a ridge, the [intercondyloid
line](/w/index.php?title=Intercondyloid_line_of_femur&action=edit&redlink=1
"Intercondyloid line of femur \(page does not exist\)"), and below by the
central part of the posterior margin of the patellar surface. The [posterior
cruciate ligament](/wiki/Posterior_cruciate_ligament "Posterior cruciate
ligament") of the [knee](/wiki/Knee "Knee") joint is attached to the lower and
front part of the medial wall of the fossa and the [anterior cruciate
ligament](/wiki/Anterior_cruciate_ligament "Anterior cruciate ligament") to an
impression on the upper and back part of its lateral wall.[3]

The articular surface of the lower end of the femur occupies the anterior,
inferior, and posterior surfaces of the condyles. Its front part is named the
patellar surface and articulates with the [patella](/wiki/Patella "Patella");
it presents a median groove which extends downward to the [intercondyloid
fossa](/wiki/Intercondylar_fossa_of_femur "Intercondylar fossa of femur") and
two convexities, the lateral of which is broader, more prominent, and extends
farther upward than the medial.[3]

Each condyle is surmounted by an elevation, the [epicondyle](/wiki/Epicondyle
"Epicondyle"). The [medial epicondyle](/wiki/Medial_epicondyle_of_the_femur
"Medial epicondyle of the femur") is a large convex eminence to which the
[tibial collateral ligament](/wiki/Tibial_collateral_ligament "Tibial
collateral ligament") of the knee-joint is attached. At its upper part is the
[adductor tubercle](/wiki/Adductor_tubercle "Adductor tubercle") and behind it
is a rough impression which gives origin to the medial head of the
[gastrocnemius](/wiki/Gastrocnemius "Gastrocnemius"). The [lateral
epicondyle](/wiki/Lateral_epicondyle_of_the_femur "Lateral epicondyle of the
femur") which is smaller and less prominent than the medial, gives attachment
to the [fibular collateral ligament](/wiki/Fibular_collateral_ligament
"Fibular collateral ligament") of the [knee-joint](/wiki/Knee-joint "Knee-
joint").[3]

### Development[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=5 "Edit
section: Development")]

Main article: [Limb development](/wiki/Limb_development "Limb development")

The femur develops from the [limb buds](/wiki/Limb_bud "Limb bud") as a result
of interactions between the [ectoderm](/wiki/Ectoderm "Ectoderm") and the
underlying [mesoderm](/wiki/Mesoderm "Mesoderm"), formation occurs roughly
around the fourth week of development.[8]

By the sixth week of development, the first [hyaline
cartilage](/wiki/Hyaline_cartilage "Hyaline cartilage") model of the femur is
formed by [chondrocytes](/wiki/Chondrocytes "Chondrocytes"). [Endochondral
ossification](/wiki/Endochondral_ossification "Endochondral ossification")
begins by the end of the [embryonic period](/wiki/Embryonic_period "Embryonic
period") and primary [ossification centers](/wiki/Ossification_center
"Ossification center") are present in all long bones of the limbs, including
the femur, by the 12th week of development. The [hindlimb](/wiki/Hindlimb
"Hindlimb") development lags behind [forelimb](/wiki/Forelimb "Forelimb")
development by 1–2 days.

## Function[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=6 "Edit
section: Function")]

As the femur is the only bone in the thigh, it serves as an attachment point
for all the muscles that exert their force over the hip and knee joints. Some
[biarticular muscles](/wiki/Biarticular_muscle "Biarticular muscle") – which
cross two joints, like the [gastrocnemius](/wiki/Gastrocnemius
"Gastrocnemius") and [plantaris](/wiki/Plantaris "Plantaris") muscles – also
originate from the femur. In all, 23 individual muscles either originate from
or insert onto the femur.

In cross-section, the thigh is divided up into three separate [fascial
compartments](/wiki/Fascial_compartments_of_thigh "Fascial compartments of
thigh") divided by [fascia](/wiki/Fascia "Fascia"), each containing muscles.
These compartments use the femur as an axis, and are separated by tough
[connective tissue](/wiki/Connective_tissue "Connective tissue") membranes (or
[septa](/wiki/Septum "Septum")). Each of these compartments has its own
[blood](/wiki/Blood "Blood") and [nerve](/wiki/Nerve "Nerve") supply, and
contains a different group of [muscles](/wiki/Muscle "Muscle"). These
compartments are named the [anterior](/wiki/Anterior_compartment_of_thigh
"Anterior compartment of thigh"),
[medial](/wiki/Medial_fascial_compartment_of_thigh "Medial fascial compartment
of thigh") and [posterior fascial
compartments](/wiki/Posterior_fascial_compartment_of_thigh "Posterior fascial
compartment of thigh").

[Popliteus muscle](/wiki/Popliteus_muscle "Popliteus muscle") | Origin | Under the [lateral epicondyle](/wiki/Lateral_epicondyle_of_the_femur "Lateral epicondyle of the femur")  
[Articularis genu muscle](/wiki/Articularis_genu_muscle "Articularis genu muscle") | Origin | Lower 1/4 of anterior femur deep to vastus intermedius  
[Gastrocnemius muscle](/wiki/Gastrocnemius_muscle "Gastrocnemius muscle") | Origin | Behind the [adductor tubercle](/wiki/Adductor_tubercle_of_femur "Adductor tubercle of femur"), over the [lateral epicondyle](/wiki/Lateral_epicondyle_of_the_femur "Lateral epicondyle of the femur") and the _popliteal facies_  
[Plantaris muscle](/wiki/Plantaris_muscle "Plantaris muscle") | Origin | Over the [lateral condyle](/wiki/Lateral_condyle_of_the_femur "Lateral condyle of the femur")  
  
## Clinical significance[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=8
"Edit section: Clinical significance")]

### Fractures[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=9 "Edit
section: Fractures")]

Main articles: [Hip fracture](/wiki/Hip_fracture "Hip fracture") and [femoral
fracture](/wiki/Femoral_fracture "Femoral fracture")

A [femoral fracture](/wiki/Femoral_fracture "Femoral fracture") that involves
the [femoral head](/wiki/Femoral_head "Femoral head"), [femoral
neck](/wiki/Femoral_neck "Femoral neck") or the [shaft of the
femur](/wiki/Shaft_of_the_femur "Shaft of the femur") immediately below the
lesser trochanter may be classified as a [hip fracture](/wiki/Hip_fracture
"Hip fracture"), especially when associated with
[osteoporosis](/wiki/Osteoporosis "Osteoporosis"). Femur fractures can be
managed in a pre-hospital setting with the use of a [traction
splint](/wiki/Traction_splint "Traction splint").

## Other animals[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=10 "Edit
section: Other animals")]

[![](//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/6c/Identification-
Classification-and-Growth-of-Moa-Chicks-%28Aves-Dinornithiformes%29-from-the-
Genus-pone.0099929.g002.jpg/220px-Identification-Classification-and-Growth-of-
Moa-Chicks-%28Aves-Dinornithiformes%29-from-the-Genus-
pone.0099929.g002.jpg)](/wiki/File:Identification-Classification-and-Growth-
of-Moa-Chicks-\(Aves-Dinornithiformes\)-from-the-Genus-pone.0099929.g002.jpg)

[](/wiki/File:Identification-Classification-and-Growth-of-Moa-Chicks-\(Aves-
Dinornithiformes\)-from-the-Genus-pone.0099929.g002.jpg "Enlarge")

Femora of [Moa](/wiki/Moa "Moa") chicks.

See also: [Arthropod leg](/wiki/Arthropod_leg "Arthropod leg")

In primitive tetrapods, the main points of muscle attachment along the femur
are the **internal trochanter** and [third trochanter](/wiki/Third_trochanter
"Third trochanter"), and a ridge along the ventral surface of the femoral
shaft referred to as the **adductor crest**. The neck of the femur is
generally minimal or absent in the most primitive forms, reflecting a simple
attachment to the acetabulum. The greater trochanter was present in the
extinct [archosaurs](/wiki/Archosaur "Archosaur"), as well as in modern birds
and mammals, being associated with the loss of the primitive sprawling gait.
The lesser trochanter is a unique development of mammals, which lack both the
internal and fourth trochanters. The adductor crest is also often absent in
mammals or alternatively reduced to a series of creases along the surface of
the bone.[10]

Some species of [whales](/wiki/Whale "Whale"),[11] [snakes](/wiki/Snake
"Snake"), and other non-walking vertebrates have
[vestigial](/wiki/Vestigiality "Vestigiality") femurs.

One of the earliest known vertebrates to have a femur is the
_[eusthenopteron](/wiki/Eusthenopteron "Eusthenopteron")_ , a
[prehistoric](/wiki/Prehistory "Prehistory") [lobe-finned
fish](/wiki/Sarcopterygii "Sarcopterygii") from the [Late
Devonian](/wiki/Late_Devonian "Late Devonian") period.

Structures analogous to the [third trochanter](/wiki/Third_trochanter "Third
trochanter") are present in mammals, including some primates.[7]

### Invertebrates[[edit](/w/index.php?title=Femur&action=edit&section=11 "Edit
section: Invertebrates")]

In [invertebrate zoology](/wiki/Invertebrate_zoology "Invertebrate zoology")
the name _femur_ appears in [arthropodology](/wiki/Arthropod "Arthropod"). The
usage is not homologous with that of vertebrate anatomy; the term "femur"
simply has been adopted by analogy and refers, where applicable, to the most
proximal of (usually) the two longest jointed segments of the legs of the
[arthropoda](/wiki/Arthropoda "Arthropoda"). The two basal segments preceding
the femur are the [coxa](/wiki/Arthropod_leg "Arthropod leg") and
[trochanter](/wiki/Arthropod_leg "Arthropod leg"). This convention is not
followed in [carcinology](/wiki/Crustacean "Crustacean") but it applies in
[arachnology](/wiki/Arachnology "Arachnology") and
[entomology](/wiki/Entomology "Entomology"). In
[myriapodology](/wiki/Myriapoda "Myriapoda") another segment, the prefemur,
connects the trochanter and femur.
